<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.

<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_BSP_Lock_Impl:

```c
void OS_BSP_Lock_Impl(void)
{
    int status;

    status = pthread_mutex_lock(&OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessMutex);
    if (status < 0)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("pthread_mutex_lock: %s\n", strerror(status));
    }
    else
    {
        /*
         * Temporarily Disable/Defer thread cancellation.
         * Note that OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl() calls write() which is a cancellation point.
         * So if this calling task is canceled, it risks leaving the BSP locked.
         */
        pthread_setcancelstate(PTHREAD_CANCEL_DISABLE, &OS_BSP_GenericLinuxGlobal.AccessCancelState);
    }
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_BSP_Lock_Impl:

void OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl(const char *Str, size_t DataLen)
{
    ssize_t WriteLen;

    while (DataLen > 0)
    {
        /* writes the raw data directly to STDOUT_FILENO (unbuffered) */
        WriteLen = write(STDOUT_FILENO, Str, DataLen);
        if (WriteLen <= 0)
        {
            /* no recourse if this fails, just stop. */
            break;
        }
        Str += WriteLen;
        DataLen -= WriteLen;
    }
}

explanation: No invocations of the string.h functions that accept pointer parameters (the functions explicitly noted by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn) are present in the provided code. The only string-related function call is strerror(status) inside the BSP_DEBUG call; strerror takes an integer and returns a pointer to an implementation-managed message string (it does not accept a user-supplied buffer pointer that could be accessed out of bounds), so it is not relevant to Rule 21.17. The OS_BSP_ConsoleOutput_Impl function uses the POSIX write() system call and pointer arithmetic on Str/ DataLen — these are not string.h library calls covered by Rule 21.17. The BSP_DEBUG macro expands to nothing, and the pthread_* calls do not use string.h functions. Therefore there are no code fragments in the given snippets that need investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17.
